title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
ML Model Robustness

ML models are trained using reference datasets tailored for a specific task.
In practice, real-world data often drifts over time from these reference datasets ‚û°Ô∏è performance degradation?
Regular retraining becomes essential.
A particularly challenging case in official statistics is the change in the classification.

2025 ‚û°Ô∏è dual labeling in both NACE R√©v. 2 and 2.1

2027 ‚û°Ô∏è full NACE R√©v. 2.1 classification while maintaining legacy NACE R√©v. 2 codes for specific usages.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Multiple Challenges

Need to recode the stock of the registry forms ‚û°Ô∏è over 14 million entries.
Building a classifier for new data flow requires a clean stock base as a training dataset.
Previous fastText model trained on over 10 million labeled entries.
Performance is highly sensitive to training data volume.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Available Data

Old registry dataset: \(~10\) million entries, but poorly suited for new labels.
New registry dataset: \(~2.7\) million entries.

Unambiguous: \(1.3\) million, covering 504 sub-classes.
Ambiguous: \(1.4\) million, covering 177 sub-classes.

Manual annotation campaign is critical.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Annotation Campaign

Annotation launched since mid-2024.
Focused on uniquely ambiguous cases.
üéØ Dual objectives:

Assign a NACE R√©v. 2.1 code üöÄ
Assess NACE R√©v. 2 code quality üó∏
Current count: \(~27k\) annotated entries‚Ä¶ still insufficient!

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Methodology

üéØ Goal: Build the most comprehensive training dataset possible.
One-shot experimentation ‚û°Ô∏è not intended for production reproducibility.
Leveraging LLMs for automated NACE R√©v. 2.1 labeling.
Data used:

New registry stock dataset (\(~2.7M\) records)
Mapping table from NACE experts
NACE explanatory notes
Manually annotated data (\(~27k\) entries)

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Leveraging LLMs

Augmented Generation (RAG/CAG) vs fine-tunning


RAG: Unstructured prior knowledge based on similarity of notes embeddings
CAG: Structured prior knowledge based on known mappings


üí° Core idea ‚û°Ô∏è Provide key information to the LLM to translate NACE R√©v. 2 into 2.1







Warning


RAG can act like a zero-shot classifier, while CAG is not a classifier as it relies on prior knowledge.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Prompt Design

A common system prompt for all entries


Afficher le prompt syt√®me

Tu es un expert de la Nomenclature statistique des Activit√©s √©conomiques dans la Communaut√© Europ√©enne (NACE). Tu es charg√© de r√©aliser le changement de nomenclature. Ta mission consiste √† attribuer un code NACE 2025 √† une entreprise, en t'appuyant sur le descriptif de son activit√© et √† partir d'une liste de codes propos√©s (identifi√©e √† partir de son code NACE 2008 existant). Voici les instructions √† suivre:
1. Analyse la description de l'activit√© principale de l'entreprise et le code NACE 2008 fourni par l'utilisateur.
2. √Ä partir de la liste des codes NACE 2025 disponible, identifie la cat√©gorie la plus appropri√©e qui correspond √† l'activit√© principale de l'entreprise.
3. Retourne le code NACE 2025 au format JSON comme sp√©cifi√© par l'utilisateur. Si la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise n'est pas suffisamment pr√©cise pour identifier un code NACE 2025 ad√©quat, retourne `null` dans le JSON.
4. √âvalue la coh√©rence entre le code NACE 2008 fourni et la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise. Si le code NACE 2008 ne semble pas correspondre √† cette description, retourne `False` dans le champ `nace08_valid` du JSON. Note que si tu arrives √† classer la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise dans un code NACE 2025, le champ `nace08_valid` devrait `True`, sinon il y a incoh√©rence.
5. R√©ponds seulement avec le JSON compl√©t√© aucune autres information ne doit √™tre retourn√©.

Each observation gets a custom prompt including:

Business activity description
Original NACE R√©v. 2 code (in CAG)
Candidate codes list from retriever

Instruction on output format required.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
fastText on production, but outdated ?

fastText: a powerful and efficient model currently used in production for NACE coding at Insee‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ but the library repo has been archived on March 19th, 2024

This non-maintenance is highly problematic in the medium-term:

Potential appearance of (non-fixable) bugs
Conflicting versions of dependencies
Modernization hindrance

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
PyTorch: why ? Some strategic reflections‚Ä¶
üí° Idea: Develop our custom PyTorch-based model to:

adapt and customize the architecture for our specific needs (text classification with additional categorical variables)
limit dependencies to external libraries and internalize maintenance for more robustness in the long-term
access to the vibrant deep learning / NLP community to develop additional features (explainability with Captum, calibration with torch-uncertainty‚Ä¶)‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ or use pre-trained models on Hugging Face

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Our solution: the torchFastText package
The package:

Provides a standard yet flexible architecture for automatic coding needs‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ that stays close to the fastText methodology for now but is led to evolve
Distributes the raw PyTorch model, a Lightning module as well as a wrapper class for a quick grip
Is open-sourced and aims at fostering collaboration ! Feel free to raise an issue, report a bug or open a PR.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
PyTorch model & Lightning module

from torchFastText.model import FastTextModel, FastTextModule
import torch

model = FastTextModel(embedding_dim=80,
                      num_classes=732,
                      num_rows = 20000,
                      categorical_vocabulary_sizes=[10, 20],
                      categorical_embedding_dims=5
                      )

module = FastTextModule(
    model=model,
    loss= torch.nn.CrossEntropyLoss(),
    optimizer=torch.optim.Adam,
    optimizer_params={"lr": 0.001},
    scheduler = None,
    scheduler_params=None
)
print(model)
print(module)

FastTextModel(
  (embeddings): Embedding(20000, 80, padding_idx=0, sparse=True)
  (emb_0): Embedding(10, 5)
  (emb_1): Embedding(20, 5)
  (fc): Linear(in_features=85, out_features=732, bias=True)
)
FastTextModule(
  (model): FastTextModel(
    (embeddings): Embedding(20000, 80, padding_idx=0, sparse=True)
    (emb_0): Embedding(10, 5)
    (emb_1): Embedding(20, 5)
    (fc): Linear(in_features=85, out_features=732, bias=True)
  )
  (loss): CrossEntropyLoss()
  (accuracy_fn): MulticlassAccuracy()
)

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Tokenizer

from torchFastText.datasets import NGramTokenizer

training_text = ['boulanger', 'coiffeur', 'boucherie', 'boucherie charcuterie']

tokenizer = NGramTokenizer(
    min_n=3, 
    max_n=6, 
    num_tokens= 100,
    len_word_ngrams=2, 
    min_count=1, 
    training_text=training_text
    )

print(tokenizer.tokenize(["boulangerie"])[0])

[['<bo', 'bou', 'oul', 'ula', 'lan', 'boul', 'nge', '<boul', 'eri', 'rie', 'ie>', 'boul', 'boul', 'oula', 'ulan', 'lang', 'ange', 'nger', 'geri', 'erie', 'rie>', '<boul', 'boula', 'oulan', 'ulang', 'lange', 'anger', 'ngeri', 'gerie', 'erie>', '<boula', 'boulan', 'oulang', 'ngerie', 'langer', 'angeri', 'ngerie', 'gerie>', '</s>', 'boulangerie </s>']]

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
The wrapper class
A quick way to launch a training in two lines of code.

from torchFastText import torchFastText

# Initialize the model
model = torchFastText(
    num_tokens=1000000,
    embedding_dim=100,
    min_count=5,
    min_n=3,
    max_n=6,
    len_word_ngrams=True,
    sparse=True
)

# Train the model
model.train(
    X_train=train_data,
    y_train=train_labels,
    X_val=val_data,
    y_val=val_labels,
    num_epochs=10,
    batch_size=64
)
# Make predictions
predictions = model.predict(test_data)

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Some obstacles:
Being a general framework, PyTorch-based models are slower than the original fastText library.

‚ö° Better to have GPU for high-scale training in reasonable time
‚ò¢Ô∏è A constraint: CPU-bound inference in production. Requires to be extremely careful regarding size of the model and pre-deployment tests.

First step has been to train a model small enough to have a response time lower than 400 ms on CPU, while keeping high prediction accuracies.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Deployment stack
MLFlow is at the core of the pipeline:

Classicly: model life cycle incl.¬†training monitoring, evaluation metric logging, model versioning‚Ä¶
And also fast deployment using a PyFunc wrapper specifically designed by MLFlow

FastAPI for API development, and Pydantic for data validation. API is deployed on a Kubernetes cluster.

title: Ongoing automatic coding projects at Insee
text:
Conclusion and next steps

‚ö†Ô∏è Transitioning to PyTorch in production requires care to deploy in production‚Ä¶
üëê ‚Ä¶ but enables to open many doors: modernization, better maintenance, state-of-the-art technology‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs well worth it !

Next steps include:

More complex architectures: attention mechanisms, more layers‚Ä¶ - to improve on the fastText methodology
Use HuggingFace: pre-trained models, tokenizers (or train a new tokenizer)
Better handling of uncertainty: calibration and conformal prediction

title: NACE R√©v. 2.1 update: Retraining an ML model in production using LLM
MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Context

Sirene is the French national company registry
When a company registers, an activity code is attributed
Early 2023:

Refactoring of the Sirene information system
Companies register through a new channel
Performance drop of the legacy coding engine
Teams already overwhelmed

Consequence: Ideal moment to innovate (but under the constraint!)

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Model

Text classification model which uses additional categorical variables
For now we use the fastText library
Originally trained on legacy data annotated partly by the coding engine and partly manually

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Current state of affairs

Model trained on Insee‚Äôs cloud data science platform üòç
Coding engine developed in Java inside of a monolithic architecture üò´

Code duplication
Reproductibility issues
Increased risk of error
Maintenance problems
No monitoring
No test data

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text: Current state of affairs

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
MLOps target

Microservice architecture running on a Kubernetes cluster

Experiment tracking and model store: MLflow
Model served via an API: FastAPI
Automation with ArgoCD
Monitoring dashboard: Quarto and DuckDB
Quality control: annotations with Label Studio

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Model store

MLflow also used as a model store
Models are packaged with all the metadata necessary to run inference
Registered models are simply loaded with this command where version is a number or a "Production" tag for example

model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(
    model_uri=f"models:/{model_name}/{version}"
)

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
API serving

Text classification model served through a containerized REST API:

Simplicity for end users
Standard query format
Scalable
Modular and portable

Multiple endpoints: batch, online
Continuous deployment with Argo CD

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text: API serving

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Monitoring

Monitoring the model in a production environment is necessary:

To detect distribution drifts in input data
To check that the model has a stable behavior
To decide when to retrain a model

Ideally, we would like to track model accuracy in real-time but expensive
In addition, monitoring of the API: latency, memory managment, disk usage, etc.

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Monitoring

How we do it:

API logs its activity
Logs are fetched and formatted periodically
Metrics are computed from the formatted logs
Display on a dashboard

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text: Monitoring

title: MLOps at Insee: a use case for text classification
text:
Quality control

Test data is gathered and annotated periodically
Annotation is done with Label Studio
Performance metrics are computed on the test data
Performance is diplayed on the monitoring dashboard
Specific retraining is necessary when specific metrics decrease under a certain threshold (not done yet)

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
üí° What will we talk about ?

MLOps pipeline for text classification at Insee
Deploying a PyTorch model on CPU-bound secured offline environment
Open-sourcing a PyTorch package: why and how

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Use case (1/2)

NACE automatic coding (code APE) for the national business registry (Sirene)

Given an activity description and some additional info, assign one of the ~750 NACE labels
Sparse-label extreme multi-class text classification task with categorical variables

If model is not confident, human annotators enter the loop (reprise manuelle)

The automatic coding model reliability is highly critical

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Use case (2/2)

Lot of training data, but not necessarily reliable

Coming from previous classification by a deterministic algorithm (Sicore) (1996-2021) and fastText (2021-2025)

Training on GPU but non-batched (online) inference on CPU (secured offline environment)

Special care about responsive inference time (<200 ms)

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text: The ideal MLOps pipeline‚Ä¶

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text: ‚Ä¶ vs ours

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Data cleaning
The first step of our pipeline (before any preprocessing or splitting) is a label correction based on expert rules:

Raw labels are coming from the previous production model: they are not fully reliable
We correct them using several techniques, based on expert-guided rules

The simplest one being REGEX (if text contains xxx then relabel as yyy)

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Extensive use of MLFLow

MLflow used as a:

Training monitor
Model store and ‚Äúversioner‚Äù
Model wrapper (using pyfunc object from MLFLow)


Models are packaged with all the metadata necessary to run inference

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
The wrapper

class MLFlowPyTorchWrapper(mlflow.pyfunc.PythonModel):
  def __init__()
    ...
  
  def predict(self, model_input: list[SingleForm], params=None) -> list[PredictionResponse]:
    query = self.preprocess_inputs(
            inputs=model_input,
        )

    # Preprocess inputs
    text = query[self.text_feature].values
    categorical_variables = query[self.categorical_features].values

    ...

    all_scores = []
    for batch_idx, batch in enumerate(dataloader):
        with torch.no_grad():
            scores = self.module(batch).detach()
            all_scores.append(scores)
    all_scores = torch.cat(all_scores)
    probs = torch.nn.functional.softmax(all_scores, dim=1)

    ...

    responses = []
    for i in range(len(predictions[0])):
        response = process_response(predictions, i, nb_echos_max, prob_min, self.libs)
        responses.append(response)

    return responses

@router.post("/", response_model=List[PredictionResponse])
async def predict(
    credentials: Annotated[HTTPBasicCredentials, Depends(get_credentials)],
    request: Request,
    forms: BatchForms,
    ...
    num_workers: int = 0,
    batch_size: int = 1,
):
    """
    Endpoint for predicting batches of data.

    Args:
        credentials (HTTPBasicCredentials): The credentials for authentication.
        forms (Forms): The input data in the form of Forms object.
        num_workers (int, optional): Number of CPU for multiprocessing in Dataloader. Defaults to 1.
        batch_size (int, optional): Size of a batch for batch prediction.

    For single predictions, we recommend keeping num_workers and batch_size to 1 for better performance.
    For batched predictions, consider increasing these two parameters (num_workers can range from 4 to 12, batch size can be increased up to 256) to optimize performance.

    Returns:
        list: The list of predicted responses.
    """
    input_data = forms.forms

    ...

    output = request.app.state.model.predict(input_data, params=params_dict)
    return [out.model_dump() for out in output]

Monitoring the model in a production environment is necessary:

To detect distribution drifts in input data
To check that the model has a stable behavior
To decide when to retrain a model

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Beyond fastText ?

fastText: a powerful and efficient model that has been used in production since 2021‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ but the library repo has been archived on March 19th, 2024

This non-maintenance is highly problematic in the medium-term:

Potential appearance of (non-fixable) bugs
Conflicting versions of dependencies
Modernization hindrance

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
PyTorch: why ? Some strategic reflections‚Ä¶
üí° Idea: Develop our custom PyTorch-based model to:

adapt and customize the architecture for our specific needs (text classification with categorical variables)
limit dependencies to external libraries and internalize maintenance for more robustness in the long-term
access to the vibrant deep learning / NLP community to develop additional features (explainability with Captum, calibration with torch-uncertainty‚Ä¶)‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ or use pre-trained models on Hugging Face down the road (when we have GPUs in production‚Ä¶)

title: torchFastText: Modernizing the MLOps pipeline at Insee for text classsification
text:
Our solution: the torchFastText package
The package:

Provides a standard yet flexible architecture for automatic coding needs‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ that stays close to the fastText methodology for now but is led to evolve
Distributes the raw PyTorch model, a Lightning module as well as a wrapper class for a quick grip
Is open-sourced and aims at fostering collaboration ! Feel free to raise an issue, report a bug or open a PR.

    model=model,

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Contexte

De plus en plus de mod√®le ML sont vou√©s √† √™tre mis en production √† l‚ÄôInsee cf GU√âD√àS et MAUREL (2024)

Multiples cas d‚Äôusages de codification : COICOP, NA2008, PCS2020, APE
üéØ Pr√©sentation ax√©e sur l‚ÄôActivit√© Principale Exerc√©e (APE) des entreprises

R√©vision de la Nomenclature d‚ÄôActivit√©s Fran√ßaise (NAF):

Adaptation au nouveau paysage √©conomique
coordination avec la r√©vision europ√©enne de la NACE

Des innovations d‚Äôautres INS sur la recodification par LLM notamment Iva Spakulova (2024)
Concurrence forte et mondiale dans le secteur de l‚ÄôIA g√©n√©rative: course au compute et aux donn√©es cf l‚Äôessai de Sutton (2019),
Litt√©rature abondante et en plein essor: Patrick Lewis (2020), RANA (2025), Connor Shorten (2024), Haoyu Huang (2025)


‚ÄØL‚ÄôInsee aboutit de plus en plus √† la mise en production de mod√®les de machine learning pour la codification dans diff√©rentes nomenclatures‚ÄØ: produits, entreprises, et d‚Äôautres entit√©s. Nous nous concentrons sur l‚ÄôAPE, l‚ÄôActivit√© Principale Exerc√©e, qui repose sur la NAF, r√©cemment r√©vis√©e pour mieux refl√©ter la r√©alit√© √©conomique.
En termes d‚Äôinnovation, l‚Äôexploration du moment est l‚Äôutilisation de LLM, comme le font certains instituts au Royaume-Uni. Le secteur de l‚ÄôIA g√©n√©rative √©volue tr√®s rapidement‚ÄØ: nouveaux mod√®les sortent r√©guli√®rement, la litt√©rature est abondante et il y a beaucoup de joyeuset√©s √† d√©couvrir dans ce domaine.‚ÄØ¬ª

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
section: La source des donn√©es d‚Äôentreprises et des libell√©s d‚Äôactivit√©s
text:
La source des donn√©es d‚Äôentreprises et des libell√©s d‚Äôactivit√©s



Loi PACTE


√Ä partir du 1er janvier 2023, l‚Äôensemble des formalit√©s d‚Äôentreprise doit √™tre d√©pos√© en ligne aupr√®s d‚Äôun organisme unique.




Pour comprendre comment l‚ÄôAPE est codifi√©, il faut d‚Äôabord savoir d‚Äôo√π viennent les libell√©s d‚Äôactivit√© des entreprises. Tout commence avec la loi PACTE. Depuis janvier 2023, toutes les formalit√©s d‚Äôentreprise doivent √™tre d√©pos√©es en ligne aupr√®s d‚Äôun organisme unique, le Guichet Unique.


INPI = Institut National de la Propri√©t√© Industrielle

Office des brevets
Op√©rateur du Guichet Unique des Entreprises (GUE)


Dans ce contexte, un nouvel acteur entre en sc√®ne : l‚ÄôINPI. Loin de se limiter aux brevets ou √† la propri√©t√© industrielle, il g√®re d√©sormais le portail du Guichet Unique, qui devient la source principale des d√©clarations pour le r√©pertoire Sirene.




Principal flux d‚Äôalimentation des d√©clarations du r√©pertoire Sirene
Fin des Centre de Formalit√©s des Entreprises (CFE)
‚û°Ô∏è description libre du libell√© d‚Äôactivit√©: texte non-structur√©


Afficher un exemple de libell√© d‚Äôactivit√©

 Je souhaite d√©velopper dans le nettoyage et entretien des bureaux d'entreprise : changelent de poubelles , aspirateur, serpill√®re



La mise en place du portail change la donne. Aujourd‚Äôhui, le r√©pertoire Sirene d√©pend de l‚ÄôINPI pour fournir les donn√©es n√©cessaires √† l‚Äôattribution du code APE.
Avant, les d√©clarants passaient par plusieurs Centres de formalit√©s : leurs libell√©s d‚Äôactivit√© √©taient guid√©s, relus et en grande partie normalis√©s. Maintenant, avec le Guichet unique, chaque d√©clarant d√©crit librement son activit√© principale avec toutes les cons√©quences que cela entra√Æne sur la qualit√© du contenu saisi.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Le r√©pertoire Sirene
Sirene = Syst√®me Informatique pour le R√©pertoire des Entreprises et de leurs √âtablissements

R√©pertoire de r√©f√©rence historique g√©rant le cycle de vie des entreprises
garant du SIREN, SIRET et de l‚ÄôAPE bas√© sur la NAF
Bascule de Sirene 3 √† Sirene 4 ‚û°Ô∏è traitement en flux
Sicore inefficient face au volume √† traiter et particuli√®rement diversit√© des libell√©s


On peut se demander quel est le r√¥le ou simplement qu‚Äôest ce que Sirene dans ce contexte. Depuis les ann√©es 70, Sirene est le r√©pertoire de r√©f√©rence qui suit la vie des entreprises, de leur cr√©ation √† leur cessation, parfois m√™me leur r√©activation. Il attribue le SIREN, le SIRET et le fameux code APE, celui que vous voyez sur vos tickets de caisse.
L‚Äôann√©e derni√®re, Sirene a connu une refonte historique : fini le monde du tout par batch, o√π le d√©clarant devait attendre le prochain traitement. Aujourd‚Äôhui, tout se fait en flux continu, quasi en temps r√©el. √Ä l‚Äôinstant o√π je vous parle, des entreprises sont en train d‚Äô√™tre enregistr√©es.
Dans ce contexte, avec un volume √©lev√© et une grande vari√©t√© de libell√©s, l‚Äôancien syst√®me expert Sicore ne suffisait plus : il surchargeait les √©quipes et ne permettait de codifier que 30‚ÄØ% des cas.


‚û°Ô∏è Mis en place d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage supervis√© fin d‚Äôann√©e 2022.

Fin 2022, un classifieur supervis√©, bas√© sur le machine learning, a √©t√© mis en place, permettant d‚Äôautomatiser au moins 65‚ÄØ% du codage du code APE, avec une d√©marche prudente consistant √† pr√©senter les autres cas en reprise gestionnaire.




√©volution dans le temps des activit√©s ou des descriptifs ‚û°Ô∏è d√©rive des donn√©es
Cas extr√™me courant pour la statistique publique ‚û°Ô∏è changement de nomenclature

Malgr√© l‚Äôabsence naturelle de donn√©es, comment entra√Æner notre mod√®le en NAF 2025 ?

Un mod√®le supervis√© n‚Äôest pertinent que si les donn√©es qui l‚Äôont entra√Æn√© restent coh√©rentes avec la r√©alit√©. Or, les activit√©s et leurs descriptifs √©voluent avec le temps : c‚Äôest ce qu‚Äôon appelle la d√©rive des donn√©es. Dans ces situations, il faut r√©entra√Æner le mod√®le.
Un cas extr√™me, fr√©quent en statistique publique, se produit lorsqu‚Äôil y a un changement de nomenclature, comme avec la NAF. Autrement dit, les valeurs possibles de notre variable cible (notre Y) changent, rendant les codes pr√©c√©dents obsol√®tes.
Alors, comment entra√Æner un mod√®le sur la NAF 2025, malgr√© l‚Äôabsence de donn√©es pour cette nouvelle version ? C‚Äôest ce que nous allons explorer.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
NAF 2025 : les cas multivoques

Au niveau 5 : 746 sous-classes contre 732 auparavant
181 classes multivoques, correspondance 1-pour-N ‚û°Ô∏è cas probl√©matiques ! üö©
Besoin d‚Äôun expert pour d√©terminer le nouveau code



Dans la nouvelle NAF, de nombreux codes √©clatent et apparaissent de nouveaux cas. Certains cas sont univoques : correspondance 1-pour-1, facile √† convertir. Mais les multivoques (1-pour-N) sont probl√©matiques : une simple bijection ne suffit pas, il faut l‚Äôexpertise d‚Äôun humain pour interpr√©ter correctement le libell√© d‚Äôactivit√©.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Combien repr√©sentent-ils ?
Jeu d‚Äôapprentissage issues de Sirene 4: \(~2.7\) millions d‚Äôobservations

C‚Äôest un volume cons√©quent. On pourrait esp√©rer que la majorit√© des cas soient univoques et que les multivoques restent rares‚Ä¶




Peu en th√©orie




Table¬†1: Repr√©sentation des multivoques dans la table de correspondance





Part de multivoques
Part d‚Äôunivoques




25 %
75 %








Beaucoup en pratique




Table¬†2: R√©pr√©sentation des multivoques dans le jeu d‚Äôapprentissage





Part de multivoques
Part d‚Äôunivoques




52 %
48 %









Faux espoirs ! M√™me si les multivoques semblent minoritaires dans la table de correspondance th√©orique, la r√©alit√© du jeu d‚Äôapprentissage est diff√©rente. La distribution des codes fait que plus de la moiti√© des observations √† recoder sont multivoques. C‚Äôest cons√©quent et pas automatisable facilement, car il faut l‚Äôintervention humaine.



‚û°Ô∏è \(~1.4\) millions de multivoques √† recoder manuellement !

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Campagnes d‚Äôannotation
Actions possibles: attribuer un code, d√©l√©guer la t√¢che ou classer comme incodables

Pour convertir le jeu d‚Äôapprentissage, nous avons men√© deux campagnes d‚Äôannotation. Chaque annotateur pouvait attribuer un code, d√©l√©guer la t√¢che ou marquer le libell√© comme inclassable.



En NAF rev 2 ou NAF 2008: gold standard pour √©valuer la pr√©cision

10 000 annotations pour valider la qualit√© dans la nomenclature actuelle
P√¥le Qualit√© Sirene ‚û°Ô∏è 6 annotateurs √† l‚Äôaveugle, sans aide √† la codification



Cette premi√®re campagne visait √† s‚Äôassurer de la qualit√© du codage actuel. Le gold standard est ici un jeu de test fiable, qui permet d‚Äô√©valuer la pr√©cision d‚Äôun classifieur avant de passer √† la NAF 2025. N‚Äôayant aucune exp√©rience en NAF 2025 au d√©part, il √©tait essentiel de v√©rifier que le codage NAF rev 2 √©tait fiable, pour pouvoir s‚Äôappuyer dessus ensuite.




En NAF 2025: ground truth pour servir de r√©f√©rence

30 000 annotations sur les donn√©es multivoques uniques
r√©seau complet des experts APE ‚û°Ô∏è environ 25 annotateurs
avec proposition de codes multivoques en fonction du code en NAF rev 2



Cette seconde campagne s‚Äôappuie sur le codage NAF rev 2 pour annoter plus rapidement et efficacement. La seconde campagne cr√©e la v√©rit√© terrain ou ground truth, c‚Äôest-√†-dire un √©talon de r√©f√©rence pour nos LLM et classifieurs. Elle permet aussi de former les experts √† la NAF 2025 et de clarifier certaines r√®gles de classement et d√©marches. M√™me avec 30 000 annotations, ce n‚Äôest pas suffisant pour entra√Æner un classifieur, mais c‚Äôest une √©tape essentielle pour constituer ce qu‚Äôon appelle une v√©rit√© terrain ou ground truth.




6¬†% de t√¢ches d√©l√©gu√©es
6¬†% de libell√©s inclassables


Un point int√©ressant √† noter : dans les deux campagnes, le taux de t√¢ches d√©l√©gu√©es et de libell√©s inclassables est identique, ce qui serait int√©ressant √† comparer avec d‚Äôautres projets d‚Äôannotation.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Concilier l‚Äôexpertise et l‚Äôinnovation

Dans quelle mesure, peut-on tirer profit des LLM ?

Nous savons que les humains seuls ne peuvent pas labelliser suffisamment de donn√©es. Mais √† l‚Äô√®re des LLM et compte tenu du contexte pr√©sent√©, des m√©thodes innovantes peuvent compl√©ter l‚Äôexpertise humaine.
L‚Äôexpert apporte une compr√©hension fine et non native aux LLM, tandis que le robot peut traiter un plus grand nombre de cas.
L‚Äôid√©e : tirer parti des deux en s‚Äôinspirant du mode op√©ratoire des experts et en utilisant les libell√©s annot√©s comme √©talon pour guider les LLM.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
M√©thodologie

üéØ Objectif : Reconstruire un jeu d‚Äôentra√Ænement le plus exhaustif possible
üí°Principe : consid√©rer les LLMs comme des annotateurs virtuels



Le principe est de reproduire le travail des experts par LLM et de s√©lectionner le mod√®le qui s‚Äôaligne le mieux avec les annotations manuelles.
Les cas univoques sont recod√©s via une table de correspondance.
Les cas multivoques sont recod√©s via LLM. Cela permet de cr√©er une base d‚Äôapprentissage volumineuse pour entra√Æner le classifieur.
En r√©sum√© : les multivoques sont labellis√©s virtuellement par LLM.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Le prompting

Prompt syst√®me identique pour toutes les observations


Afficher le prompt syt√®me

Tu es un expert de la Nomenclature statistique des Activit√©s √©conomiques dans la Communaut√© Europ√©enne (NACE). Tu es charg√© de r√©aliser le changement de nomenclature. Ta mission consiste √† attribuer un code NACE 2025 √† une entreprise, en t'appuyant sur le descriptif de son activit√© et √† partir d'une liste de codes propos√©s (identifi√©e √† partir de son code NACE 2008 existant). Voici les instructions √† suivre :
1. Analyse la description de l'activit√© principale de l'entreprise et le code NACE 2008 fourni par l'utilisateur.
2. √Ä partir de la liste des codes NACE 2025 disponible, identifie la cat√©gorie la plus appropri√©e qui correspond √† l'activit√© principale de l'entreprise.
3. Retourne le code NACE 2025 au format JSON comme sp√©cifi√© par l'utilisateur. Si la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise n'est pas suffisamment pr√©cise pour identifier un code NACE 2025 ad√©quat, retourne `null` dans le JSON.
4. √âvalue la coh√©rence entre le code NACE 2008 fourni et la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise. Si le code NACE 2008 ne semble pas correspondre √† cette description, retourne `False` dans le champ `nace08_valid` du JSON. Note que si tu arrives √† classer la description de l'activit√© de l'entreprise dans un code NACE 2025, le champ `nace08_valid` devrait `True`, sinon il y a incoh√©rence.
5. R√©ponds seulement avec le JSON compl√©t√© aucune autres information ne doit √™tre retourn√©.

Un prompt sp√©cifique pour chaque observation comprenant :

le libell√© de l‚Äôactivit√© principale de l‚Äôentreprise
l‚Äôancien code NAF 2008 connu
La liste des codes possibles issues du mapping avec leurs notes explicatives

Une instruction sur le format de r√©ponse attendu



Afficher un exemple de r√©ponse attendue

{
    "codable": true,
    "nace_2008_valid": true,
    "nace2025": "0147J" 
}


Le LLM a besoin de directives claires pour produire des r√©ponses fiables : Prompt syst√®me : d√©finit sa feuille de route globale, lui donne un r√¥le d‚Äôexpert NACE. C‚Äôest un exemple parmi les nombreuses techniques du prompt engineering pour optimiser les LLM. Prompt sp√©cifique : fourni pour chaque observation, avec les informations n√©cessaires pour coder correctement, et surtout pour ajouter le contexte. Nous verrons quelques exemples pour comprendre pourquoi c‚Äôest crucial. Consigne de format : pour √©viter les r√©ponses volubiles ou incorrectes et garantir une sortie structur√©e et exploitable.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Importance du contexte


Sans contexte suffisant, le LLM peut halluciner, c‚Äôest-√†-dire fournir des r√©ponses incorrectes ou invent√©es. Pour coder correctement en NAF 2025, il est indispensable de lui fournir le contexte n√©cessaire.

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Injection du contexte
*

C‚Äôest pour cela que l‚Äôon ajoute du contexte. Il existe diff√©rentes techniques dont la plus populaire est le RAG. Le sch√©ma pr√©sente le contexte inject√© qui constitue notre prompt sp√©cifique ou requ√™te. La quantit√© de texte que le LLM peut examiner est appel√©e fen√™tre de contexte (sur le sch√©ma, rep√©r√©e comme ‚Äúfen√™tre √©tendue‚Äù).

title: Les LLM au coeur du r√©entra√Ænement d‚Äôun mod√®le d‚Äôapprentissage en nouvelle nomenclature
text:
Pr√©cisions par mod√®le









Figure¬†1: Comparaison fastText vs torchTextClassifiers







En entra√Ænant notre classifieur sur le nouveau jeu d‚Äôapprentissage, nous obtenons des performances similaires √† celles de la nomenclature actuelle.
Comme dans toute d√©marche classique de machine learning :

Split train/test/validation pour √©valuer la performance
Data editing du jeu d‚Äôapprentissage pour corriger les cas probl√©matiques avant la mise en production

Notre futur mod√®le s‚Äôappuiera sur la librairie TorchTextClassifiers, qui sera pr√©sent√© (par mon coll√®gue, ici pr√©sent ?) Jeudi apr√®s-midi dans cette m√™me salle.
Cette conclusion montre que notre m√©thodologie, combinant annotations humaines, LLM et expertise, permet de constituer une base fiable et performante pour la NAF 2025. Elle n‚Äôest pas limit√©e √† une nomenclature donn√©e ni √† un classifieur particulier et peut √™tre adapt√©e √† toute probl√©matique similaire, ouvrant des perspectives int√©ressantes en mati√®re d‚Äôinnovation.

Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Machine learning in official statistics

Today, machine learning systems contribute effectively to the production of official statistics
Coding engines, data editing: outlier detection, imputation
CoP: ‚ÄúSource data, integrated data, intermediate results and statistical outputs [must be] regularly assessed and validated‚Äù and ‚Äúrevisions [must be] regularly analysed in order to improve source data, statistical processes and outputs‚Äù
This naturally applies when ML systems are leveraged in the process of producing statistics

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Quality of ML systems

A ML model is trained to solve a task based on reference data
Real-life data can deviate from the reference data, which leads to performance issues
Retraining is necessary to avoid these issues

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Description of the coding system

Sirene is the French national company register
When a company registers, an activity code is attributed
A model trained on historical Sirene data is used when it is confident enough. Otherwise, the description is given a code manually

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text: Modeling

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Performance

Evaluation on historical data: very high accuracy of 89%
With newer hand-coded data: reduced accuracy of 80% due to a distribution shift in the data
Company activities evolve over time. New businesses appear, businesses traditionally associated with a certain activity may see this activity evolve, etc.

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Design

The model is served via a REST API (developed with FastAPI)
A process fetches logs daily, parses them and saves their content on a persistent storage
An interactive dashboard is built with Quarto to offer insight on data and how it is coded

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Dashboard

Dashboard tab offering daily and weekly insight on the number of queries to the API and its automatic coding rate.

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Dashboard

Dashboard tab displaying the two distributions of predicted classes at a specified level of the classification system for two specified time windows.

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Continuous performance evaluation

We continuously increment an evaluation set to monitor the performance of the ML system
Batches are sampled from recent Sirene data and uploaded onto Label Studio
For now data is shared between annotators and each description is coded once (could change in the future)
The dashboard is enriched with additional tabs leveraging evaluation data

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Continuous performance evaluation

Dashboard tab giving insight on the monthly accuracy of the evaluation set.

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Periodic retraining

Company activities evolve over time. A first strategy is to retrain the model periodically
How frequently ? There is a tradeoff as there should be a validation procedure to use a new model in production

In our case, distribution shifts are not large. It is reasonable to retrain twice a year

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
Additional retraining

Additional specific retraining procedures can be triggered:

When the monitoring system detects unusual shifts in the data
When repeated claims are made by certain companies on their activity code
When coding concepts change

title: Retraining strategies for an economic activity classification model
text:
What training data ?

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Context

Several major changes:

Internal: Revamping of the French company registry, Sirene 4.
External: Implementation of a one-stop shop to declare the creation of a business.

Observation: Sicore is no longer a suitable tool ‚û® 30% automated coding.
Consequence: Ideal moment to propose a new methodology for automated NACE coding.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Data

\(\approx\) 10 million observations from Sirene 3 covering the period 2014-2022.
Data labeled both by Sicore and manually.
An observation consists of:

A textual description of the activity
The nature of the activity ‚Äì NAT (23 categories)
The type of form ‚Äì TYP (15 categories)
The type of event ‚Äì EVT (24 categories)
The area (\(m^2\)) ‚Äì SUR (4 categories)

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Feature extraction

Word embedding: a method of vectorisation.
Pre-trained embeddings available in open-source.
We learn our own word embeddings.
Additionally, embeddings for:

word n-grams and character n-grams.

title: Classifying companies in France using machine learning
text:
Linear classifer

2 classification methods:

Softmax: a single multiclass classifier.
One-vs-all: multiple binary classifiers.

Optimisation: stochastic gradient descent algorithm.
Loss function: cross-entropy.

Models have been deployed in a production environment since November 2022.
Emerging new challenges include:

Organisational issues.
Real-time monitoring.
Regular re-training.

MLOps approach is required:

Join us on Wednesday, June 7th for a Hands-on Lab!
